Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Galois Action and Entropy in Non-archimedean Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project concerns a number of open problems in non-archimedean dynamics, a field on the interface between number theory and traditional (archimedean) dynamical systems. This project joins together the very different realms of dynamical systems and of number theory. Diophantine problems, which ask about the set rational number solutions to polynomial equations, have been a major theme in number theory from ancient times to the present day. On the other hand, the study of dynamical systems has arisen far more recently, exhibiting not only a purely mathematical beauty but also spectacular computer drawings of fractals and related sets. This project draws on, builds on, and joins together both fields. In addition, as in three earlier successful projects, the investigator plans to supervise some students in an REU summer research project to aid in their mathematical training. Any computational data produced in the REU will be published or posted on the web, for the benefit of the larger research community. Naturally, any results will also be disseminated via websites such as ArXiv and publication in mathematical journals. In addition, the PI is currently writing a graduate-level textbook on dynamics in one non-archimedean variable, as the field has too few expository texts today.

One key class of problems concerns Galois actions on non-archimedean dynamical systems, related to the central number theory problem of understanding the absolute Galois group of the rational numbers. On the one hand, non-archimedean dynamics provides the local information needed in arithmetic dynamics, which in turn realizes itself as a particular kind of Diophantine problem. A second class of problems concerns the ergodic properties, especially the entropy, of such dynamical systems; the entropy is a number that measures the amount of chaos and unpredictability in the system. These two topics are tied together by the study of Julia sets in Berkovich spaces, which are technical objects that, in the past decade, have proven to be of central importance in the study of non-archimedean dynamics. The project also draws on tools from complex dynamics, ergodic theory, and non-archimedean analysis. The problems to be studied branch into new areas but are continuations of rich theories with long and storied histories. In particular, the Galois action problem promises to provide new (dynamical) tools for attacking the study of absolute Galois groups, while the study of the associated entropy issues promise to provide new examples in the study of the ergodic theory of dynamical systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The focus of this project was arithmetic dynamics, a field bridging the interface between dynamical systems (popularly known as chaos theory) and number theory. In the past decade or two, it has become clear that two technical objects are of great importance in the field: Berkovich spaces on the one hand, and arboreal Galois groups on the other. The PI tackled a number of open questions surrounding these objects, using mathematical tools that have been developed only in the past few years.

One key result of the project, in joint work with Jamie Juul, was to prove most cases of a 1985 conjecture of Odoni, about the existence of maps with arboreal Galois groups that are large in a certain precise mathematical sense. A second key result, joint with Juul as well as Xander Faber, Ben Hutz, and Yu Yasufuku, was to give a full analysis of the arboreal Galois group of a particular cubic polynomial having the special property of being postcritically finite, or PCF. Maps satisfying this special condition are known to have smaller-than-usual arboreal Galois groups, and these results marked the first such analysis of a PCF map.

The PI led an REU group (Research Experiences for Undergraduates) in Summer 2017 to work on a problem inspired by the PCF cubic result, this time regarding an analysis of a certain PCF quadratic polynomial. The PI and the undergraduates in the REU group together worked out the essential details of the resulting arboreal Galois groups, and the PI finished the analysis over the ensuing months. Besides the intellectual merit of the mathematical results themselves, the REU project also had the broader impact of an intense and rewarding introduction to research for the undergraduate students involved.

The PI also completed a joint project with John Benedetto on the harmonic analysis of frames over non-archimedean fields. The main theorem in this project extended a 1993 theorem of J.Benedetto and S.Li from real vector spaces to far more general locally compact abelian groups.

The PI collaborated with Patrick Ingram, Rafe Jones, Michelle Manes, Joe Silverman, and Tom Tucker to produce an extensive expository survey article on open problems in arithmetic dynamics. This article should provide a useful entry point to early-career mathematicians looking to study problems in the field, as well as serving as a reference and a source of numerous open problems.

Another major result of the project was the completion and publication of the PI's graduate-level textbook on non-archimedean dynamics, and especially the use of Berkovich spaces in this field. There has been a need expressed by scholars and graduate students interested in the field for such a resource, and the PI has the necessary expertise inthe subject and familiarity with the relevant literature. The PI developed the text from some rough notes into a textbook giving a broad, deep, and detailed exposition of the full theory in a single resource. The book, which appeared in print in April 2019, now serves as a resource for researchers in the field, as well as for the training of graduate students and other early-career mathematicians.
